content.description:
This sit-start is extremely height-dependent and ranges from V8-9 to V12ish depending on your span.

Sit start with left hand on obvious jug and right hand on an undercling. Make a big move up and right to a sidepull, and throw left to the start hold of

Smith Overhang

. If you are tall enough (i.e. >6 feet) to go jug-to-jug up the thing without ever moving your feet, it is probably closer to V9 (and a good one at that). The problem gets increasingly harder the shorter you are as you have to make the crux move off of poorer and poorer holds. For me at 5' 10" , using the 2nd-worst hold, it's more like V10+. For someone like Peter Beal who is shorter, it's probably more like V12-13 because he has to use the worst hold on the wall.

Nevertheless, it's a great addition to the Schwagstaff circuit regardless of how you climb it.

climbs.name: Smith Overhang
climbs.fa: Richard Smith, 1967 (but surely not the V8 version? Chip?)

content.description:
This is one of Flagstaff's best problems and requires a maximum of body tension.  For the V8, start on the slick as snot right hand sidepull and either a pinch or mono for the left.  Pop up with the left to the glued side pull and continue making hard moves to the slopey topout.  You have to want this one bad to send it.

For the easier start (maybe V6?), start from a cheat stone with the right hand on the slick sidepull and the left in the glued, high, opposing sidepull.  Make the same moves to the top.
content.protection: Bring a pad because one can pop off with explosive force from a number of moves.

climbs.name: Pratt's Overhang
climbs.fa: Bob Culp & Kenny Parker in the early 1960s

content.description: Pratt's Overhang takes on the obvious, right-leaning slot in the middle of the formation. A few easy moves takes you to the crux at the top. Expect a bit of a grovel no matter how you do it. It is much harder than it looks. A good extension is to start from the good holds low and left on the mantel problem, making it V4 or V5.
content.protection: A couple of pads will be welcome.

content.description: This starts in the bottom, left corner on a juggy ledge.  It then traverses up and right past a two finger pocket and some slopey crimps to a decent slopey rail.  Then, throw up and left to a top ledge and mantle up.  It requires some high feet and is a little sketchy, but it is well worth climbing.
content.location:
The boulder is the one on the left that you pass on the way down to

Monkey Traverse

.  It is right along the trail and is hard to miss.

content.description: It's a gully with a crack. This is a bit tricky to get started and then eases up after a couple moves.
content.location:
Gully is just right of

Crystal Corner

and just left of the tree.

content.description: While the Gill Swing is an eliminate, it is still one of the best problems on Flagstaff.  Starting on the right corner of Smith Overhang on side pulls/undercuts at about five feet, jack your feet up and go for the lip of the boulder.  From what I understand, Gill did this problem without touching anything between the starting holds and the lip.  A direct sit start can be done that knocks the grade up to around v5/6.
content.protection: The landing has some roots and rocks so bring a bouldering pad.

content.description:
Begin as for

Gill Swing

on a "down-facing edge but use the obvious crystal to gain the top."  The "crystal" is more of a smooth pebble that has been split in half.  Body tension helps to establish onto the problem but even after that it is stiff at V2.
content.protection: A crashpad or two is enough, but a spotter is recommended.
content.location: This is on the far right side of Pratt's Overhang.

content.description:
Start on the low holds under

Pratt's Mantle

(farthest left side of the wall).  Double dyno up to the sloping lip, get your feet up, and mantle over.

It is lots of fun.  The easiest way to do this is to hit it right the first time.  Otherwise, I think you'll scrape your tips a bit when you swing out.  The mantle (if you do it pure - no edge to the right) seems a hell of a lot harder than the dyno, but I guess those old school dudes (Pratt, etc.) were pretty burly.
content.location:
This is under

Pratt's Mantle

(on the farthest left side of the wall).
